title: Umurhan 2008: 177–178 discusses the generic resonance of the chariot imagery (equos) in 1.19–21 that helps Lucilius define his satire against the genre of epic and the image’s Callimachean undertones

note: For a discussion of Juvenal on Lucilius, see Freudenburg 2001: 242–248. See also Goldberg 2005: 173–177 and Keane 2006.
title: Fragments of Lucilius are notated according to Warmington 1979

note: On the pomerium in general see Rüpke 1990: 30–41, Beard, North, and Price 1998: 1.177–181, Andreussi 1999, Rehak 2006, Goodman 2007: 42–46, and Jacobs II and Conlin 2014: 187n6.
title: On the ritual significance of the pomerium see Andreussi 1999, Varro De Lingua Latina 5.143, Plutarch Romulus 11.1–4. According to Tacitus, the emperor Claudius connects the territorial expansion of the empire and its city with the pomerium (Annals 12.23–24). Drogula 2007 argues that imperium as military command was banned inside of the pomerium
